Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:600X-8JX1-JB3N-T0B3-00000-00Donald Trump is a lunatic: Wikipedia co-founder Jimmy Wales2020-05-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:40:39ZLexisNexisWORLD NEWSDonald Trump is a lunatic: Wikipedia co-founder Jimmy WalesChandra R Srikanth

Wikipedia co-founder Jimmy Wales hit out at US President Donald Trump on his plans to regulate social media companies, stating that while social media must be careful about information on their platforms, it's not a good idea for governments to threaten them. In an exclusive interview to ET NOW, he also spoke about fighting fake news in India and tackling misinformation arising out of the Covid19 crisis. "If President Trump tweets something that is nonsense we don't accept that as a source of information for random things he says on Twitter.

We have a group of admins who are very strict and firm on what can be entered," Wales said, in an exclusive television interview from London. President Trump and Twitter have been on a warpath after the social media platform posted fact-check links with some of his tweets. Trump accused Big Tech of silencing conservative voices on platforms and is expected to sign an executive order clamping down on social media on Thursday. It is not clear yet if he has the power to do something as drastic as shutting down the platforms.Wales said it is a complicated issue and that social media platforms should have robust, diverse dialogue and fight armies of troll bots that put out misinformation. "President's power does not extend to threatening or shutting down social media platforms. But we should fear this in every country.Worst case scenario is that platforms don't have courage to tell Trump to go away, that they begin to adapt policies to his whims because he is a lunatic," Wales said Late last year, Wales launched his own social media platform called WT:Social to take on Facebook and Twitter. But instead of an ad-funded model, he intends to fund it via donations. "I would rather build something that has quality and meaningful engagement than adopt techniques for rapid and viral growth. It can be sustainable/" Wikipedia's pages on Covid10 has racked up over 100 million views in recent months, making it a go-to source for information on the pandemic and its fallout. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

urn:contentItem:60GG-C8R1-DY0W-416J-00000-00DONALD TRUMP JR., EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, THE TRUMP ORGANIZATION IS INTERVIEWED ON FBN'S "LOU DOBBS TONIGHT"2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:40:39ZLexisNexisDONALD TRUMP JR., EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, THE TRUMP ORGANIZATION IS INTERVIEWED ON FBN'S "LOU DOBBS TONIGHT"LanhamFULL TEXT

DONALD TRUMP JR., EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, THE TRUMP ORGANIZATION IS INTERVIEWED ON FBN'S "LOU DOBBS TONIGHT"

JULY 29, 2020

SPEAKERS: DONALD TRUMP JR., EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, THE TRUMP ORGANIZATION

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST

[*] LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Well joining us tonight who knows something about the power of Big Tech and Silicon Valley, we're joined by Donald Trump Jr., Executive Vice President of The Trump Organization, bestselling author and of course, son of President Donald Trump.

Don Jr.'s Twitter account was restricted yesterday after twitting a video highlighting the benefits of hydroxychloroquine.

Don, it's great to have you with us on the show. Can you hear me?

DONALD TRUMP JR., EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, THE TRUMP ORGANIZATION (via phone): Yes.

DOBBS: First, I've got to -- good. I want to ask you, first of all, your reaction to being suspended by Twitter for effectively promoting that video extolling the benefits of hydroxychloroquine.

TRUMP JR.: Well, I didn't even say anything about it. What was interesting about it, Lou, I think we're having a little technical difficulties because I'm in the van. I'm actually doing this now in the vehicle because the satellite feed isn't working.

But I simply said, this is an interesting counterpoint to what you're hearing and the narrative that you're getting every day from Democrats. And, you know, and/or the mainstream media.

It was a group of doctors, about a dozen of them and they were talking about, hey, we've treated real patients with it. We've seen this, why is that there? So I said, this is interesting. People should listen to this. People should hear and hear a dissenting opinion.

I didn't say it was right or wrong, and for that, I got thrown off of Twitter for 12 hours. It happened to numerous other people as well, and it's amazing that the doctors at Twitter apparently know more than actual life medical professional, dozens of them that were standing on the steps of Congress with some congressmen.

DOBBS: Mark Zuckerberg today obviously making it very clear to the assembled congressmen that he didn't have anything to do with your suspension or Sidney Powell, General Flynn's defense attorney, her account, but saying at the same time that he didn't want to be an arbiter of truth that his company was doing precisely that, that Twitter, he acknowledged was doing exactly that deciding what is valid, what is invalid, what is true and that isn't their role nor is it their prerogative under our Constitution to do so.

What are -- what are we going to do? We are watching this hearing today, but I don't know it's going to solve much.

TRUMP JR.: I don't know that it's going to solve much because Republicans have to wake up to this problem and then obviously, Mark Zuckeberg is Facebook, the issue I had was with Twitter.

But you know, they all do the same thing. I see it, Instagram which is owned by Facebook did the same thing to me last year when I called out the Jussie Smollett hoax before everyone because I just said, hey, this is ridiculous and I got thrown off Instagram for a while with my post taken down for apparently perpetuating hate speech.

I didn't say anything. I actually said, has anyone even bothered to look into this story because it seems really, really, really ridiculously farfetched.

It turns out, I was right, but that didn't stop them from labeling me as someone who provoked hate speech, that didn't stop then the media from taking that and running with it that I'm promoting conspiracy theories.

You know, it's not -- it's only a conspiracy theory until you're proven right, which I obviously was. That said, it didn't change anything.

So the problem we have in Congress is that many Republicans, they don't know anything about social media. They're not on it. Some young staffer is doing it. They don't see these things.

And more importantly, they're not in touch with their base, who is just deplatformed (ph), who is censored. Anyone who is religious, anyone who is a Second Amendment supporter, anyone who is pro-life, all of those things are just destroyed and decimated in the algorithms of social media.

And frankly, even in the search engines like Google, look at what Google did to Breitbart. It doesn't end and Republicans are not aware of it. They keep saying it is nonsense, that it's a free market principle. It's not a free market when you're getting government protection.

These companies get billions of dollars' worth of free liability protections from the government. They cannot then function as publishers deciding what you and the American people get to see and what they don't, pushing their liberal, California bordering on communist agenda to the American people because they're attempting to sway in the election.

They're attempting to sway in the way that people think, and it's very effective when people -- ordinary people who don't see what's going on are bombarded with a one-sided, incredibly biased, left-wing, talking point memo on a daily basis on these platforms.

DOBBS: It's truly stunning, the awesome power that these giant tech companies, social media companies with them are exerting on American society right now. It is -- it's stunning.

It is also un-American for this to continue under our antitrust laws, and yet, as you say the Republicans act like scared children when you mention regulating what is obviously monopolistic and anti-competitive behavior.

It is absolutely a juvenile response on the part of Republicans who should know something about economics and politics. Let's talk about politics real quickly. It looks to me like a number of the polls are turning in your father's direction. The President is looking, I think, significantly stronger, despite the polling biases of most of these organizations, your thoughts?

TRUMP JR.: Listen, I think you're right. Again, there's a lot for us to overcome when you talk about that bias. You know, Lou, you and I do this stuff every day. We're watching it 2/7, but for the average person who is, you know, working hard to put food on their table, you know, they're consuming five minutes of news a day and it's 96 percent negative against Donald Trump.

There are people, you know, quote-unquote "professional journalists," who are still perpetrating the Russia hoax nonsense and everything. I mean, it's very hard to overcome that. People have to understand what's going on. People have to understand Joe Biden's path because of quarantine.

I had a few months off. I wrote another book called "Liberal Privilege." It's available on donjr.com, you know, you know, D-O-N-J-R dot com because I basically had four months to look into the background of this 50-year career swamp creature, and he is not the guy that the mainstream media is pushing. He is not the moderate that you think he is.

He is not this reasonable guy, and honestly, if you want Joe Biden and you see the way he behaves, you see how he can't remember where he is. He's just a pawn for the radical left and all you have to do is look on his website and see these Biden standards, communist manifesto joint unity plan to realize that this is a radical guy who is not in charge.

The radical left will be in charge of this Biden presidency, if that ever, God forbid happens, and it will be the end of America as we know it, Lou.

DOBBS: Donald Trump Jr., good to have you with us. Come back soon. All the best and we'll get to these technology problems sorted out between you and us. Thanks a lot, Don.

END

urn:contentItem:60GF-6DB1-F15W-H036-00000-00DONALD TRUMP JR., EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, THE TRUMP ORGANIZATION IS INTERVIEWED ON FOX NEWS2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:40:39ZLexisNexisDONALD TRUMP JR., EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, THE TRUMP ORGANIZATION IS INTERVIEWED ON FOX NEWS

July 30, 2020

NEWS PROGRAM

DONALD TRUMP JR., EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, THE TRUMP ORGANIZATION

AINSLEY EARHARDT, FOX NEWS HOST: Let's bring in Donald Trump Jr., executive vice president of The Trump Organization and President Trump's son. Good morning to you, Don.

DONALD TRUMP JR., EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, THE TRUMP

ORGANIZATION: Good morning, guys. How are you?

EARHARDT: We're doing well.

I know that your Twitter account -- you posted that hydroxychloroquine video and your account was suspended.

TRUMP JR.: Yes.

EARHARDT: So what's your reaction to what happened yesterday with these big-tech CEOs?

TRUMP JR.: Well, listen, there's no question that there's bias. Ainsley, if you're religious, if you're pro-life, if you're pro-Second Amendment, you watch your metrics and you watch them get destroyed.

Conservatives and people who believe in conservative values have been targeted by these people who have no problem allowing a platform of free speech to the Ayatollah, to Communist China, to people who are committing genocide. That's not a problem.

But I post a video that's just an alternative thought -- a different viewpoint by actual doctors -- doctors -- not some kooks. These were a dozen doctors on the Capitol steps with a congressman -- and that was spreading misinformation.

But when the Chinese Communist government literally spread disinformation about coronavirus, they literally said -- Twitter said that is not a violation of their rules. The Chinese government spreading disinformation is not a violation of their rules.

But me saying hey, this is interesting, it's very different than the narrative that they've been cramming down our throats -- maybe you should watch it and make up your own minds -- that was enough to get thrown off the platform.

PETE HEGSETH, FOX NEWS HOST: And, Twitter tells us they're an American company, Don. But you mentioned China. You also briefly mentioned Iran.

Well, Twitter didn't find time to go to Capitol Hill. I think they probably knew they would get the most scrutiny of any organization. But a representative for Twitter did tell the IsraeliCongress that Iran's supreme leader is not in violation of Twitter rules but your father, the president, is.

Take a listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ARSEN OSTROVSKY, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, JEWISH-ISRAELI CONGRESS: You have recently started flagging the tweets of President Trump. Why have you not flagged the tweets of Iran's Ayatollah Khamenei, who has literally called for genocide of Israel and the Jewish people?

TWITTER SPOKESWOMAN: Well, we have an approach to world leaders that presently say that direct interactions with fellow public figures, comments on political issues of the day, or foreign policy saber-rattling on military-economic issues are generally not in violation of our Twitter rules.

MICHAL COTLER-WUNSH, MEMBER, KNESSET, BLUE AND WHITE ALLIANCE: And calling for genocide is OK, but commenting on politics --

TWITTER SPOKESWOMAN: However --

COTLER-WUNSH: -- is not? Just so we understand. Just so -- I just want to fine-tune the question. Calling for genocide on Twitter is OK, but commenting on political situations in certain countries is not OK?

TWITTER SPOKESWOMAN: Well, if a world leader violates our rules, but it is a clear interest in keeping that up on the servers, we may place it behind a notice that provides some more context.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HEGSETH: So, Don, it seems like Twitter is America first, it's just blame America first and the rest of the world gets a pass.

TRUMP JR.: Yes. I mean, it's truly disgusting. I mean -- and again, you don't have to be a genius to see it. I see what they've done to my analytics. Every time I push a button, I know what it's going to do. I do enough of this stuff.

And my numbers, my retweets, my likes -- you know, they're cut in half or even in third compared to what I was probably doing six months ago. You see that this is a ramp-up for an election.

But more importantly, you hear that response. How insane is this? I mean, there really is a word for what these people are full of, I just can't say it on the air. And it's time to end it.

Republicans have to wake up also because they're not even aware most of the time. Their staffers are online doing these things. The average Republican in Congress --

HEGSETH: That's true.

TRUMP JR.: -- has no idea what's actually happening on these platforms. And so, they don't even realize a) what's going on, and b) how important it is for their base who is being totally suppressed, their free speech wiped away while these companies get a lot of protections from the government.

And that's the key. If they're getting these liability protections -- these companies are getting probably the equivalent of billions of dollars of protections from lawsuits, from this -- then they can't act as publishers and decide what --

HEGSETH: Right.

TRUMP JR.: -- the American people will see based on their opinions.

BRIAN KILMEADE, FOX NEWS HOST: See, Don, there's two things. I actually believe both Republicans and Democrats are alarmed about the power, for different reasons, of those behemoths that were there yesterday.

But I would need -- there needs to be some action before November third. It's not good to rant to people who understand what you're going through. Somehow, they've got to get into their algorithm and change things. And we seem to be saying the same thing for the last three years.

Meanwhile, the president is fight -- he's got to fight for Texas. It's pretty close. Loses Texas, Republicans are not going to win for a generation.

And there, he was tapping into exactly what fuels Texas and that's oil and gas. He believes that if Joe Biden's elected president, we'll go back into the Paris Accord and eventually, fracking's gone.

Although, Joe -- although, Joe Biden says oh, fracking's fine with me.

What are we to believe?

TRUMP JR.: Well, it's not what he's said in the past, first and foremost.

But if you look at the sort of Green New Deal in another name only, Joe Biden, on his Web site, is basically saying hey, we're going all to clean energy. We're getting rid of fossil fuels. We're doing this all in the next few years. I think it was by 2030 that all of this stuff was gone.

That would destroy the economy in Texas, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Ohio. There's numerous states that are getting the benefits of being able to do this. And as Americans, the reality is we're still going to be reliant on those natural resources from other countries.

Why not do it better, cleaner, more environmentally-friendly while also employing Americans -- putting them to work and generating something for the economy? I mean, this is the notion of what Donald Trump did over the last four years -- cut the nonsense regulations, did things responsibly, allowed the free markets to work. And that's why you had the greatest economy in the history of modern America because of those policies.

Joe Biden doesn't know where he is 50 percent of the time, Pete. Joe Biden is a puppet of the left. You can see that with this -- you know, Biden standards, joint unity, communist manifesto plan. It's really scary because they're going to send America into the dark ages.

EARHARDT: So you wrote this op-ed on foxnews.com and it's titled "Biden wouldn't reduce rioting and crime -- he's controlled by left-wing puppet masters"

So when he does say he's for something, do you think that it doesn't matter what his opinions are, he's controlled by the other people -- by the progressives in the party -- and he's going to do whatever they ask him to do?

TRUMP JR.: One hundred percent. Listen, you see the videos of him. He can't get to a podium. He can't answer a question with 10 people.

You would think that if you were a D.C. swamp creature, Ainsley, you'd be able to talk to a group of 10 to 20 people without a teleprompter. He's not able to do that.

So, the media is trying to do what they do best, which is show up for the Democrats by running Joe Biden as a moderate. You'll hear he's a moderate -- you'll hear he's a moderate.

But all you have to do is actually look at the positions he's taken. These are on his Web sites. It's, by far, the most radical agenda in modern history. It's not even questioned. It's on his Web site.

But the media is going to try to get him the best of both worlds. They're going to try to run him as a moderate to people who may be watching this station and others, and then they're going to let him run as a radical to those who have lost their minds in America.

The reality is he hasn't come out against defund the police. He's all for the integration of the suburbs with the big cities so that you have high volume zonings that would destroy the American suburbs.

These are not things that we think he's going to do, Ainsley. These are things that are literally on his Web site. And that's just the beginning of it.

Free health care for illegal immigrants -- free. I'd love that, myself. I'd love free health care but I pay for it, OK?

Free housing for criminals coming out of prison. It seems like an incentive to create crime.

The list goes on and on. It's insanity.

But again, the media will do what the big tech companies are trying to do. They will try to cover. They will try to shave off some of the message so it's not getting out there, so it doesn't have the same efficacy when it gets to the people.

And they are all in this together working for the Democrats. It's not even pretend anymore. They're just doing it.

KILMEADE: Yes. And you saw a bit of a campaign -- it looked a little like a campaign yesterday. But everything's going to be so different than any campaign that we've seen.

So we'll see where this goes because the president has got to get -- find some way to get Joe Biden out of his basement regularly and maybe that's closing the gap in the polls.

EARHARDT: Yes, can I ask about that? How are they going to handle the debates?

TRUMP JR.: There's no incentive for him to come out of his basement. He does better when America doesn't see him.

When America doesn't see him forget where he is every other time. Where America doesn't see him forget who's his wife and who's his sister. Forget the office that he's running for. Needs someone to guide him through a crowd. Cut him off in an interview.

Joe Biden -- this is his dream and the Democrats' dream because you can cover up who Joe Biden is.

I actually -- you know, when I started looking at it in the beginning of quarantine, I had four months. I actually wrote a second book about it called "Liberal Privilege." Because if you look into the history of Joe Biden, what you see there is not what you're being sold today.

And that's the hypocrisy of the media and the left. It's absolutely disgusting and people really have to inform themselves before November.

HEGSETH: Yes. This will be a contrast election, no doubt.

Don Jr., thank you so much for joining us this morning. We appreciate it.

EARHARDT: Thank you.

TRUMP JR.: Thank you, guys.

HEGSETH: You got it.

END

urn:contentItem:60H4-8YX1-JBHT-D2DW-00000-00DONALD TRUMP JR., EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, THE TRUMP ORGANIZATION IS INTERVIEWED ON FOX NEWS' "WATTERS' WORLD"2020-08-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:40:39ZLexisNexisDONALD TRUMP JR., EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, THE TRUMP ORGANIZATION IS INTERVIEWED ON FOX NEWS' "WATTERS' WORLD"LanhamFULL TEXT

DONALD TRUMP JR., EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, THE TRUMP ORGANIZATION IS INTERVIEWED ON FOX NEWS' "WATTERS' WORLD"

AUGUST 1, 2020

SPEAKERS: DONALD TRUMP JR., EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, THE TRUMP ORGANIZATION

JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST

[*] JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST: Joining me now the President's son and Executive VP at The Trump Organization and author of the book "Liberal Privilege," which is available for preorder, Donald Trump Jr.

So Don, explained to me this is, so a Yale epidemiologist, he says that hydroxychloroquine can be effective in early stages of coronavirus. So if you retweet a doctor who agrees with the Yale guy, how is that misinformation? Isn't that just a second opinion?

DONALD TRUMP JR., EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, THE TRUMP ORGANIZATION: Well, I think that's what's called science, right? Science -- certain things aren't definitive. They argue back and forth, and I thought as an American, that that kind of discourse is what actually makes us American, to be able to have a dissenting opinion.

Twitter -- the great doctors at Twitter of which I believe there are none have decided that one doctor is more right than another group of doctors. I want to hear all sides, and that was what was interesting about my tweet, which is, I didn't say, everyone else was wrong. This is right.

I just go. Wow. You know, Jesse, this is really interesting. This is so different than the narrative that they've been jamming down my throat for the last three months. We should probably hear that. That was enough to get me thrown off Twitter.

Now, they didn't have a problem. Twitter did not have a problem with the Chinese government literally spreading coronavirus disinformation. There's an article in "The Hill" where they say no, the Chinese government spreading coronavirus disinformation, which by the way probably cost millions of people's their lives over the course of the world. Right? That does not violate their rules.

The Ayatollah Khomeini talking about death to Israel, you know, and genocide, that doesn't violate the rules. Me saying, I don't know, maybe you should hear from a couple of doctors who have a disagreement on this that are actually treating patients in the field. My father retweeting a meme. You know, that's enough to get us thrown off of these platforms. And that's the problem.

Big Tech is activist liberal. They are out there putting their hand and it's a very powerful hand, more powerful probably than any hand in modern history, weighing the scales down in favor of the left.

You notice, you've not heard of a single leftist, no matter whether it is moderate left or some of the radical, you know, crazy people you're seeing so much of these days on the left. You've never seen them thrown off the platform. You've never seen them suspended. You've never seen them demonetized.

WATTERS: Right.

TRUMP JR.: You don't -- you know, they don't have the same in-boxing problems.

WATTERS: Well, Don, that's because they believe --

TRUMP JR.: The Gmail and Google.

WATTERS: That you, Donald Trump Jr., are more dangerous than the Ayatollah and the Communist Chinese. Everyone -- everyone is scared of Donald Trump Jr. and you're right, because here's the deal. It's about censorship.

TRUMP JR.: I think that's a little bit of a compliment.

WATTERS: Yes, I know. You are that powerful.

TRUMP JR.: ... that much power in my fingers. It's truly --

WATTERS: You really are that big of a threat with your fingers and you don't have a finger on any nuclear buttons. It's just a retweet and retweets --

TRUMP JR.: I know. I've got nothing.

WATTERS: Yes, right. Retweets are not endorsements. That's what they tell you. You know, and this way -- you can plot Antifa riots on Twitter. They don't do anything about that. You can accuse the President of treason, the Russia collusion. That's misinformation.

You can call someone a rapist, a white supremacist. That's not hate speech at all. It's all going one way.

It's a blitzkrieg of regulation against conservative speech because they don't trust the American people to make up their own minds because if there are both sides out there and they can decide, based on the facts, you'll always choose against the totalitarian left.

TRUMP JR.: They will do whatever they can.

WATTERS: Yes.

TRUMP JR.: They will do whatever they can to push the voter to believe the radical left and to vote accordingly. That is their job in this. They've been doing it for a while. I mean, it's no secret. I've been on your show talking about, you know, social media censorship, what they're doing.

I've said in the past that everything I've seen from '16 on has been a dry run for 2020. They're not even hiding anymore. They're just doing it.

Again, if literal disinformation -- information put out by the Chinese government that places like the World Health Organization and others relied upon, that is not enough to get you thrown off of Twitter, deplatformed or censored, but me being like, I don't know, maybe you should watch this. We like to believe in free speech. Let's hear what they have to say. That's a problem.

You know, that's what we are up against, Jesse.

WATTERS: Yes, I think honestly -- yes, I think the Republicans need to threaten to break up these monopolies if they're not treated fairly.

All right, so you have Joe Biden out there. He is running for President. He is walking for President, whatever you want to call it. He's gone far left. I don't know where his brain has gone. It might just be gone.

Here he is walking to the podium the other day. I don't know if he knows where he is. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BIDEN: Good afternoon, everyone. Welcome at Kingswood Community Center. Actually, that's the one down I used to work -- that's a joke. You know where we are anyway. It's great to be here and back in a place where, you know --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: Where am I?

TRUMP JR.: Jesse, what I want to know is, when does this -- when does this start being considered elder abuse? I mean, it's really not fair.

I mean, honestly, it wouldn't be truly sad if it wasn't so scary that this guy could be in charge of the nuclear football. You see it every day.

WATTERS: He fumbles.

TRUMP JR.: He doesn't remember where he is. He forgets who his wife is. He forgets what office he is running for. He gets in front of a crowd -- and don't forget Joe Biden is a 50-year swamp creature, right?

If you've been a politician for 50 years, you should be able to get in front of a whopping crowd of seven people and be able to do it without a teleprompter.

WATTERS: You're right. It should come naturally.

TRUMP JR.: He can't do that. His team pulls him off any interview, because you see him start to go off the rails and most notably, was sort of during the debates.

Notice how -- I don't think he ever completed a question without going, well, I don't want to take up any more of your time. So I'll give my time so everyone else can speak.

He is literally the first politician in the history of politics to not go over his time in a debate and it's because he didn't remember where he was going.

He spoke for 45 seconds, forgot the point he was trying to make, forgot the question, and now he is ceding back the time because he is this magnanimous guy.

I mean, give me a break. It's not funny. I mean, we're laughing because this is the people we are, right?

WATTERS: No, I know we're laughing at it now, but it's scary.

TRUMP JR.: And I am like, this guy could be in charge.

WATTERS: And it looks like he's going to put Kamala Harris on the ticket, which is even more of a scarier idea. Not as scary as Donald Trump Jr., who everybody believes is scarier than the Iranians and the Chinese communists.

All right. Check out his book. You can order right now. Donald Trump Jr. There he is. Thanks.

TRUMP JR.: Thank you, Jesse.

END

Okay, Congressman, let's begin with immigration policy. What grade would you give the President there?

RON PAUL, FORMER PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: It depends on what day of the week it is. It's up and down.

I don't -- he doesn't get an A plus from me. I don't like walls and fences and things like that. But actually, immigration is down. I don't know whether that's because of Trump or whether he has helped do that.

You know, so illegal immigration is done. So I'd give him a low C. He doesn't get a high A and I don't think he's completely failed, because he does talk a little bit about my theory about what we do, it if you don't subsidize something, it will help. And if you do subsidize something, you get more of it.

I think the subsidies for illegally entering this country is the main motivating factor for us to have our problem.

WATTERS: So are you talking about benefits in terms of entitlements or in state tuition, things like that? Driver's licenses like they're doing here in New York?

R. PAUL: Yes. All of that for a starter, but it's also a special way to become a citizen, easy road to citizenship, jumping in front of the line and getting free education. I mean, it makes no sense at all.

All I can say is, if most Americans were put in the same situation, they'd probably be praying or hoping they could, you know, get some of that, but I just think it's divisive to do -- to take from --

WATTERS: Low C minus is a tough grade, Congressman. I mean, I would give them maybe a B plus. But you know, we just have word right now that the Pentagon -- here it is -- just transferred close to $4 billion to fund the border wall construction. So I think it's moving in the right direction. But you know, we can disagree on that.

Tell me about his economic policy. Where do you stand on that in terms of a grade?

R. PAUL: Partially I endorse, you know, most conservatives, and you don't even have to be a libertarian Austrian economist to say, lowering taxes and lowering the regulations is a good idea.

But, no, he's a long way from what Austrian economics teaches what free markets are all about. And that is, it deals with the monetary policy, it deals with the Federal Reserve. You want to have interest rates designed by the marketplace, not by putting pressure on the Federal Reserve and say get those rates down.

And on the short run, it is sort of like, you know, if people need to get ahead and they can hold somebody up, steal some money and live beyond their means or borrow the money, you know, from the Federal Reserve, you can have an appearance of a pretty good prosperity. But it will always end.

So the zero rate interest rate, it's the craziest thing ever. It's not going to work. The biggest problem with that overall is what a lot of people are admitting now, it creates a lot of debt. It's huge.

Just this week, what was it? $14 trillion per household. You know, all household debt. This is unsustainable and it could distort things --

WATTERS: Yes, I mean, but we've been saying that for what? Decades. The debt is out of control, and it just keeps on getting bigger and bigger and neither party is going to do anything about that.

Finally, so you never gave me a grade. What was the grade for economic policy? You've got to admit, you know, it's a job.

R. PAUL: C minus for tax and regulators --

WATTERS: You are a tough grader. C minus again? Wow. Geez.

R. PAUL: Yes.

WATTERS: I'd like to see your grades with Barack Obama.

R. PAUL: Somebody -- if you care about the economy, you've got to care about those people who had secretly manipulated interest rates in the money supply. They're the bosses of this whole economy and Trump knows it and he has to handle it.

WATTERS: Well, that's a longer discussion. Finally, foreign policy. I mean, I just have to step in. He is probably someone that's right up your alley. I mean, he's not starting a lot of new wars. He wants to get out of the Middle East. Clearly, you have to give him better than a C minus Congressman Paul.

R. PAUL: Well, I think we're in the same category. Let me give that some thought. But no, if we go by what he says and what he said in the campaign, you know, he deserves a B plus. I'm coming home. I'm stopping these wars.

But you know, take Syria for instance, he said that what we need to do is come home and he makes that announcement, the next day sends more troops over there.

WATTERS: There is always the second terms, you know and that's a guarantee almost.

R. PAUL: It's too much intervention for me.

WATTERS: All right. Well, I think any intervention is too much for you, but Congressman, wait, did I hear any final grade? Last on foreign policy?

R. PAUL: On foreign policy is another C minus.

WATTERS: Okay. C minus across the board.

R. PAUL: What he says though, I'd give him a B, but what happens is we're doing the same old things. We're intervening when we shouldn't be and we should be taking care of ourselves.

WATTERS: Thank you. Thank you very much, Professor. I mean, Congressman.

R. PAUL: Thank you, Jesse. Nice to talk to you.

WATTERS: Some crazy anti-Trump guy drove his van into a bunch of Trump supporters down in Florida. One of the victims of that van attack speaks out exclusively next on WATTERS' WORLD.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: All of a sudden, he hit the gas and plowed into us.

QUESTION: How close did he come to hitting people?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Probably maybe about half a foot.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Twenty-seven-year-old Gregory Timm is sitting in jail after police say he ran into a Republican voter registration tent.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This individual drove up to a tent that was clearly registering voters with Donald Trump's name and attire around them.

It looks like political attack to me.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: Last weekend's van attack in Florida was politically motivated and it's been barely covered by the media.

Joining me now with this reaction, one of the victims of the attack, Mark Alfieri. So Mark, did you get the sense that he was trying to plow the van into you or just trying to kind of crash into the tent?

MARK ALFIERI, VAN ATTACK VICTIM: Well, initially, you know, the -- you know, the shock of it, he approached us kind of about a 45-degree angle. He was waving at us. He was smiling, making it appear like he was going to stop the van, get out and start talking with us, as many, many people had done that afternoon, when he just accelerated and plowed right into the tent, overturning the tent, our tables, all of our equipment and the volunteers, including myself, having to scatter.

WATTERS: Wow, he almost kind of set you up, made you feel at ease by waving and smiling and then accelerated. How close did he come to you guys?

ALFIERI: He came very close, you know, especially to the two women -- the two female volunteers that were with me. He came very close to them, and that resulted in two of the felony criminal accounts that are pending now against him.

WATTERS: How fast was he going about?

ALFIERI: Gosh. Difficult to say. It was just, you know, it was so quick him plowing into the tent to overturning tables, cell phones flying everywhere. It was pretty shocking.

WATTERS: Yes. So he gets out of there according to all of you and the witnesses. He flips you off. I guess he gets back in the van and drives away. Now, he told police that he did this because he does not like Donald Trump and he wanted to take a stand. He said, "Someone had to take a stand." Is this a hate crime in your opinion?

ALFIERI: I believe it would be a hate crime. I mean, it was just -- it was a very deliberate act, and like I was mentioning before, there was, you know, a fair amount of deception in it before he actually rammed the van into our tent and tables.

So, you know, I believe it was a hate crime and definitely politically motivated. Some pretty intense feelings against President Trump.

WATTERS: How do you feel about the fact that this has barely been touched by the media? I think, CBS, ABC, they never even covered it. I think NBC touched on it for a few seconds. How does that make you feel?

ALFIERI: I think it's pretty incredible actually and just you know, it's kind of outrageous that the most of the national media did not cover it, because we had, you know, people, myself doing a civic duty and this this crime -- this felony crime that was committed pretty, pretty outrageous that it was not covered.

WATTERS: All right, Mark I'm glad you're okay. I'm glad everybody else is okay and I hope this guy is prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law. Thanks for joining WATTERS' WORLD.

ALFIERI: Thank you.

WATTERS: Up next, a very special Presidents Day Last Call.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: The big war under his presidency --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: World War?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: President's Day is Monday, so what better way to honor those who have held office then with a look back at how much people really know about these leaders?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: What are you doing today to commemorate the Presidents?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Basically, I'm trying to earn some dead Presidents.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I don't do the President thing.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP FROM MOVIE "NACHO LIBRE.")

JACK BLACK, ACTOR, PLAYING "NACHO": You've got to be kidding me.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: I'm going to hold up some pictures of some of the Presidents. You just tell me what you think. Okay?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Abraham Lincoln.

WATTERS: Not Lincoln.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: George --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: George Washington. Okay. The first President.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Thomas Jefferson, right?

WATTERS: Wow. Thomas Jefferson. All right. Who's this?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: George Washington.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: George Washington.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Here's the biggest pot farmer in American history.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Sexy.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Abe. Honest.

WATTERS: Honest Abe. A big war under his presidency.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: World War. World War II.

WATTERS: You remember who won the Civil War?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I think we won.

WATTERS: Who is we? California?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I don't know.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: America.

WATTERS: The North or the South?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The South.

WATTERS: President during World War II?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I don't know.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It wasn't Clinton, right? No.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: FDR.

WATTERS: FDR. You're on fire, lady.

(VIDEO CLIP OF MOVIE "HOME ALONE.")

WATTERS: Who is this?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: That one is Teddy Roosevelt.

WATTERS: Oh my god, you nailed it.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Good job.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Yes.

WATTERS: Now, he has famous saying, "Speak softly and carry a big --"

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Heart.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Brain.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Hammer.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Pickle? Broccoli?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Ah [bleep].

WATTERS: Carry a big --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Stick.

WATTERS: Well done.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I knew that one.

WATTERS: Do you ever watch WATTERS' WORLD?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What? "Waterworld" the movie?

(VIDEO CLIP OF MOVIE "WATERWORLD")

WATTERS: I'm Watters. And this is my world. It's my world right here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: You know, I still stay in touch with that guy with his shirt off. I really do. He is still living out there on the beach in Malibu.

To see more of my favorite "Man on the Street" interviews, be sure to check out Season 7 of classic WATTERS' WORLD, now available on Fox Nation.

That's all for tonight. Be sure to follow me on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter. "JUSTICE WITH JUDGE JEANINE" is next, and remember I'm WATTERS, and this is my WORLD.

urn:contentItem:5VNX-YT01-JCMN-Y23N-00000-00Donald Trump Junior: Conservatives face a tough fight as Big Tech's censorship expands2019-03-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:40:39ZLexisNexisDonald Trump Junior: Conservatives face a tough fight as Big Tech's censorship expandsThe Hill

Mar 19, 2019( The Duran: http://theduran.com Delivered by Newstex) As Big Tech's censorship of conservatives becomes ever more flagrant and overt, the old arguments about protecting the sanctity of the modern public square are now invalid. Our right to freely engage in public discourse through speech is under sustained attack, necessitating a vigorous defense against the major social media and internet platforms. From 'shadowbans' onFacebook[1]andTwitter[2], todemonetization of YouTube videos[3], topulled[4]ads for Republican candidates at the critical junctures of election campaigns, the list ofviolations against the online practices and speech of conservatives[5]is long. I certainly had my suspicions confirmed when Instagram, which is owned by Facebook, 'accidentally' censored[6] a post I made regarding the Jussie Smollett hoax, which consequently led to me hearing from hundreds of my followers about how they've been having problems seeing, liking or being able to interact with my posts.

Many of them even claimed that they've had to repeatedly refollow me, as Instagram keeps unfollowing me on their accounts.ADVERTISEMENTWhile nothing about Big Tech's censorship of conservatives truly surprises me anymore, it's still chilling to see the proof for yourself. If it can happen to me, the son of the president, with millions of followers on social media, just think about how bad it must be for conservatives with smaller followings and those who don't have the soapbox or media reach to push back when they're being targeted? Thanks to a brave Facebook whistleblower whoapproached[7]James O'Keefe's Project Veritas, we now know that Mark Zuckerberg[8]Mark Elliot Zuckerberg[9]Conservatives face a tough fight as Big Tech's censorship expands[10] Actually, consumers love Big Tech, even if they say they don't[11] Top Instagram communications staffer leaves for Michelle Obama's staff[12] MORE[13]'s social media giant developed algorithms to 'deboost' certain content, limiting its distribution and appearance in news feeds. As you probably guessed, this stealth censorship was specifically aimed at conservatives. Facebook appears to have deliberatelytailored[14]its algorithm to recognize the syntax and style popular among conservatives in order to 'deboost' that content. 'Mainstream media,' 'SJW" (Social Justice Warrior) and 'red pill' — all terms that conservatives often use to express themselves — were listed as red flags, according to the former Facebook insider. Facebook engineers even cited BlazeTV host Lauren Chen's video criticizing the social justice movement as an example of the kind of 'red pills' that users just aren't allowed to drop anymore. Mainstream conservative content wasstrangled[15]in real time, yet fringe leftists such as the Young Turks enjoy free rein on the social media platform. Despite the occasionalbrave gesture[16], politicians have been far too sluggish in recognizing the extent of the problem. But the Republican Party and the conservative movement are becoming more vigilant against the suppression of our speech, as we saw at last weekend'sConservative Political Action Conference (CPAC)[17].ADVERTISEMENTSilicon Valley lobbyists have splashedmillions of dollars[18]all over the Washington swamp to play on conservatives' innate faith in the free-market system and respect for private property. Even as Big Tech companies work to exclude us from the town square of the 21st century, they've been able to rely on misguided conservatives tocarry water[19]for them with irrelevant pedantry about whether the First Amendmentapplies[20]in cases of social media censorship. Sen. Josh Hawley[21]Joshua (Josh) David Hawley[22]Trio of NFL players intern on Capitol Hill as part of league program[23] Conservatives face a tough fight as Big Tech's censorship expands[24] Hirono calls out Trump for 'appalling' comments she says encourage violence[25] MORE[26] (R-Mo.) has beenmaking[27]a name for himself as a Republican prepared to stand up to Big Tech malfeasance since his time as Missouri's attorney general. Hedelivered[28]a tour de force interview with The Wall Street Journal's Kimberly Strassel in front of the CPAC crowd, one that provided a clear-eyed assessment of the ongoing affront to the freedoms of conservative speech and expression. Hawley demolished the absurd notion that 'conservative principles' preclude taking action to ensure free debate online simply because Big Tech firms — the most powerful corporations in the world — are private companies. Hawley pointed out that Big Tech companies already enjoy 'sweetheart deals' under current regulations that make their malfeasance a matter of public concern. Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, for instance, allows them to avoid liability for the content that users post to their platforms. To address this problem, Hawley proposed adding a viewpoint neutrality requirement for platforms that benefit from Section 230's protections, which were originallyenacted[29]to protect the internet as 'a forum for a true diversity of political discourse.' 'Google and Facebook should not be a law unto themselves,' Hawley declared. 'They should not be able to discriminate against conservatives. They should not be able to tell us we need to sit down and shut up!' It's high time other conservative politicians started heeding Hawley's warnings, because the logical endpoint of Big Tech's free rein is far more troubling than conservative meme warriors losing their Twitter accounts. As we're alreadystarting to see[30], what starts with social media censorship can quickly lead to banishment from such fundamental services as transportation, online payments and banking. Left unchecked, Big Tech and liberal activists could construct a private 'social credit' system — not unlike what the communists have nightmarishlyimplemented[31]in China — that excludes outspoken conservatives from wide swaths of American life simply because their political views differ from those of tech executives. There is no conservative principle that even remotely suggests we are obligated to adopt a laissez-faire attitude while the richest companies on earth abuse the power we give them to put a thumb on the scale for our political enemies. If anything, our love of the free market dictates that we must do whatever is necessary to ensure that the free marketplace of ideas remains open to all. Donald Trump Jr.[32]Donald (Don) John Trump[33]Conservatives face a tough fight as Big Tech's censorship expands[34] GOP lawmaker defends Chelsea Clinton after confrontation over New Zealand attacks[35] Trump Jr. defends Chelsea Clinton after confrontation at vigil for New Zealand attacks[36] MORE[37] is executive vice president at The Trump Organization. urn:contentItem:5H83-0FF1-DXH2-6499-00000-00Donald Trump Losing; Business Headlines; White House and congressional leaders reach an agreement on a two year budget deal that also extends the debt limit; Wal-Mart wants to use drones to make deliveries to your front door, check warehouse inventories and curbside pickup; The Baltimore Ravens missing a chance to tie up the game on final play against the Arizona Cardinals; REI going dark on Black Friday; Dreamworks Animation CEO, Jeffrey Katzenberg, credits TESLA's CEO, Elon Musk, and the Model S with his survival after a life-threatening car accident in Hollywood on October 19; New York Mayor, Bill De Blasio, reportedly endorsing Hillary Clinton for president2015-10-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:40:39ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTJon Hilsenrath, Stephen Wood, Phil Flynn, David Malpass; Dr. Devi NampiaparampilNEWSFinancial102702cb.231Donald Trump Losing; Business Headlines; White House and congressional leaders reach an agreement on a two year budget deal that also extends the debt limit; Wal-Mart wants to use drones to make deliveries to your front door, check warehouse inventories and curbside pickup; The Baltimore Ravens missing a chance to tie up the game on final play against the Arizona Cardinals; REI going dark on Black Friday; Dreamworks Animation CEO, Jeffrey Katzenberg, credits TESLA's CEO, Elon Musk, and the Model S with his survival after a life-threatening car accident in Hollywood on October 19; New York Mayor, Bill De Blasio, reportedly endorsing Hillary Clinton for presidentSandra Smith, Blake Burman, Dagen McDowell, Lo Ling Kent, Cheryl Casone

SANDRA SMITH, FBN ANCHOR: Trump making more controversial comments, especially on women wearing burkas.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: In fact, it's easier. You don't have to put on make-up. Look how beautiful everyone looks. Wouldn't it be easier? Wha (ph). Right? Wouldn't that be easy? I'll tell you, if I was a woman, I don't want to - wha, I'm ready, darling, let's go. It's true.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SMITH: This as Trump loses more ground to Ben Carson, who, by the way, is garnering a big chunk of the female vote in Iowa. More on this straight ahead.

A showdown at sea. The U.S. sending a warship near one of China's artificial islands in the South China Sea.

Turning to markets this morning. It's a busy day on earnings and the economic calendar. Futures showing markets right now pointing to a lower open on Wall Street two and a half hours from now. Small losses as we kick off this Tuesday morning.

Tech also in play. Both Apple and Twitter reporting earnings after the close of trading today.

And a look at markets trading overseas as we look at London in negative territory, off 0.4 percent. The leader to the downside in Europe right now is the CAC Quarante in France, down 0.4 percent.

Walmart taking a page out of Amazon's playbook. The retail giant wants to use drones to make deliveries. The company filing for regulatory approval to do so.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: (INAUDIBLE) back. Pressure on. To the middle. (INAUDIBLE). And then secured and intercepted by Tony Jefferson (ph).

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SMITH: The Baltimore Ravens missing a chance to tie up the game on the final play against the Arizona Cardinals. Ravens quarterback Joe Flacco intercepted in the end zone and Arizona won the game 26 to 18.

And it's a big night for baseball. The World Series getting underway tonight in Kansas City. I've got fist pumping on set going on. It's set to be a pricey series for fans. The average ticket price right now $723. That's according to Stub Hub. And it gets even more expensive when the teams face off in New York next Wednesday - or, sorry, on Wednesday. That price is surely to be steeper than that.

As I mentioned earlier, Donald Trump losing considerable ground in Iowa while making more controversial comments in a New Hampshire town hall meeting. Blake Burman has the latest from Washington for us this morning.

Blake, good morning.

BLAKE BURMAN, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hi there, Sandra. Good morning to you.

Donald Trump still holds commanding leads nationally and in a couple of the early voting states, but there's a growing trend in Iowa according to the polls taken there over the last week. Dr. Ben Carson has supplanted Trump in the first caucus state. Carson has won four of the last five polls, as you can see here, with the fifth being a tie. They are all fairly sizable spreads, with the most recent from Monmouth University showing Carson with a 14 point lead.

In the meantime, Trump is facing some scrutiny now for a couple of comments he made yesterday in New Hampshire. In one of them, Trump said it's easy for women to wear burkas because they don't have to wear makeup.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: In fact, it's easier. You don't have to put on make-up. Look how beautiful everyone looks. Wouldn't it be easier? Wha (ph). Right? Wouldn't that be easy? I'll tell you, if I was a woman, I don't want to - wha, I'm ready, darling, let's go. It's true.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: And, separately, Trump also took credit for Ford's decision to halt truck production plans in Mexico and stay in Ohio. However, Sandra, that was strongly disputed by both Ford and the Ohio Governor and Presidential Candidate John Kasich.

Back to you.

SMITH: All right, Blake, thank you.

BURMAN: Thanks.

SMITH: Dagen, we're going to ask you for your comments on Trump's comments, about women in burkas and -

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Where did he - where was he giving that speech? Checky's (ph) Shack (ph) down in Boca Raton. Hey, I'll be here all week, try the veal. That's what it was like. That's - it's not president but I don't think anybody who's a fan of his really cares, do they?

SMITH: Well, it's interesting because here we're talking about how Dr. Carson in now - he's now won three of the last four major polls in Iowa and, Jon, one of the biggest demographics that he is successful with right now and gaining ground with is women.

JON HILSENRATH, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": Well, you know, I think - listening to Trump there, I think he really runs the risk of wearing out his welcome. I mean like you say, Dagen, this - he sounds like a bad stand- up comedian. Is that really what we want for the presidency? As far as Carson goes, you have to wonder, I mean America doesn't really know him. You have to wonder what kind of staying power he's going to have as people get to know him a little bit better.

SMITH: Well, the race is surely changing. Ted Cruz gaining some steam, as you pointed out last hour. Marco Rubio at 10 percent. Is the playing field changing?

HILSENRATH: It does look like - I think it is changing. I think you see people like Cruz coming up and you have to keep an eye on him. As - as - as -

MCDOWELL: And Carly is - Carly Fiorina has kind of lost her appeal to voters out -

HILSENRATH: Yes, that's - I was wondering about that.

MCDOWELL: That she had that incredible debate performance but she's kind of receded a little bit and I wonder what it would take to move her back up.

HILSENRATH: You have to wonder is, these Fox Business debates come up in a couple weeks, if that's going to be a stage for her to reassert herself, because that's going to be all of that business in the economy.

SMITH: Well, a GOP debate tomorrow night as well on the economy.

HILSENRATH: Right.

SMITH: So that would be an opportunity, obviously, for her to shine. We'll see if that happens. But, yes, Carly Fiorina not on the top five in that most recent poll. So, all right, guys, thank you.

Big day for tech earnings with Apple and Twitter set to release quarterly numbers after today's close. Jo Ling Kent is here and joins us on set. She's talking Ali Baba.

JO LING KENT: Yes. We are seeing some big mobile revenue jumps, which is always good news for an ecommerce company. A huge earnings day. Ali Baba beat on the top and bottom just a few minutes ago. Revenue came in at $3.49 billion, beating that $3.35 billion the street was looking for. Plus, EPS of $0.57 a share, beating that expected $0.54 estimate. Gross merchandize volume was up 28 percent, revenue was up 32 percent, so some very big moves there for Ali Baba, especially as they go into singles day, their biggest sales day of the year, which comes up in November.

And T-Mobile earnings out later this hour. Expectations of $8.28 billion in revenue with $0.30 on EPS.

Ford also just out moments ago posting mixed results, $38.1 billion in revenue. That's a beat of the $35.07 billion the street was looking for. But adjusted EPS coming in just shy at $0.45, of that $0.46 estimate.

And then after the bell today, two big name in tech, of course. Apple's fiscal fourth quarter expected to post revenue of $1.11 billion with $1.88 in EPS. And the pressure really is on here for iPhone sales, Apple Watch, also looking at China as that slows down, if they're able to sustain momentum there.

And we're also going to be watching Twitter as well. This is the first earnings report since Jack Dorsey was named the permanent CEO. EPS expected of $0.05 a share. Revenue expected at $560 million. Now, that one is all about monthly active user growth plus these new products. Twitter Moments, is it resonating? Our users actually picking up and changing their behavior and sticking around on Twitter?

SMITH: So do you expect some good news for - for Twitter then?

KENT: It could be better but it may not get better for a while in terms of permanent growth in the positive direction. Jack Dorsey has a lot of work to do, even though everyone's pretty glad that he's back.

SMITH: Right.

MCDOWELL: I will say the delivery of ads on Instagram is top notch compared to all other social media applications.

KENT: Yes.

MCDOWELL: But this - so targeted. Interesting ads, video -

KENT: Seamless.

MCDOWELL: Seamless. And -

KENT: And you've seen that in FaceBook earnings, too, it's really working.

SMITH: Right. He's - he's sitting right next to me. I want to bring him in. Russell Investments chief market strategist Stephen Wood.

What do you expect out of these big tech giant, Apple, Twitter, optimism?

STEPHEN WOOD, RUSSELL INVESTMENTS: I think so. I think there's going to be a bright spot in earnings in the Q3 and it's not going to come from much of the S&P 500. So I think where we're going to get firmer earnings is going to be in tech. I think we need to look at Apple and kind of back that out. I can't comment on a specific company, when will you back out Apple earnings. I think it's going to be a challenged third quarter and one of the - the less dim spots is going to be in tech.

SMITH: Less dim spot is going to be in tech. OK. So you kind of, sort of like technology I guess at this point.

WOOD: Yes. Yes. And as -

HILSENRATH: Steve -

WOOD: Yes, sir.

HILSENRATH: What are you getting from the conference calls that you're listening in on? We had a story in the paper yesterday that pointed to dimming expectations among CEOs for the outlook for growth in the U.S. and overseas. Are you picking up on any of that yourself?

WOOD: I think we are. We - it's - well, this has been a top line challenge environment for a long time. Companies have been pretty good at hitting their earnings numbers for a large number of quarters, you know, pushing half a decade, but we really haven't seen any movement in revenue and sales and I think that's really starting to push into the front quarter. But I think what - one of the bigger stories is going to be what happens in December with the Fed and our job is not to be like a total nerd fest here talking about the Fed.

SMITH: Yes.

(CROSS TALK)

MCDOWELL: You know, actually, that is what his job is -

WOOD: I know.

MCDOWELL: Is (INAUDIBLE) Fed nerd.

KENT: I like it.

WOOD: Fed nerd. And I'm with you. No -

SMITH: I just tweeted out, hash tag nerds on set with us.

WOOD: Nerds on set.

SMITH: Yes.

WOOD: Book-ended by nerds here. But I think the oil story, which has really challenged not only debt and equity space for the first week quarters as we go into 2016, some of the benefits from oil come into the economy and I think that's going to be a little bit of a lift.

SMITH: Do you think we're going to see it?

WOOD: I think so. Well, if you're an energy company, you've got to recognize all those losses in the first and second quarter. But if you're a consumer, you're not going to buy 12 months of gasoline in the first week of January. It takes you 12 months to pay 12 electric bills, to pay 12 energy bills. So I think as we move into this quarter, the fourth quarter, and the first quarter of next year, you begin to see some modest improvement based upon the drop in energy prices.

HILSENRATH: I thought Jo - so Jo Ling just reported all these earnings numbers. What - what you reported, the one that I found most interesting was Ford's top line. That Ford beat expectations on its revenue growth.

KENT: Yes.

HILSENRATH: We have a car sales boom going on in this country right now.

WOOD: Yes.

HILSENRATH: People are - they - they haven't recognized it.

WOOD: Unreported, yes.

HILSENRATH: But - well, actually, we had a front-page story about it before the last Fed meeting. But I think that's an example of consumers finally starting to kick in and driving growth. It will be interesting to see what the other automakers have.

(CROSS TALK)

WOOD: And that's an interesting - if you look at China too, the consumer story, the industrial story is well known in China, but the consumer story, and it's positive in China is probably less well covered, and I think you get some of that effect in the United States as well.

MCDOWELL: Well, speaking of -

HILSENRATH: Do you really believe that they're making that transition in China or -

WOOD: No, I do believe that they're making that transition. No matter what, they will make that transition. That's a government policy -

KENT: But do you believe the numbers behind that transition right now?

WOOD: I think believe in numbers is a strong statement.

KENT: OK.

WOOD: Coming out of China.

HILSENRATH: So are you buying emerging markets? Are you buying China?

WOOD: I would not say buying Chinese right now. I think that the - the Chinese government is going to transition from that export-oriented, more consumers based economy and that is going to create challenges and commodity based emerging market. So it might be a little bit early on emerging market, but valuations are starting to look attractive. They're beginning to bottom out in the cycle. We know that China's a 7 percent, 6.5 percent grower. That's going to happen.

MCDOWELL: Can I -

WOOD: And the question is, whether it is priced in, in emerging markets.

MCDOWELL: I'm trying to promote Jon's story, because he's got a story on the front page of "The Wall Street Journal" today, and the central issue this week and this year will be the Federal Reserve. And I read every word in your story and it was - it basically shows a Fed that's a mess.

HILSENRATH: Well, Janet Yellen has a hard job on her hands on two fronts. One is that the economy is hard to read right now. You would expect inflation to be kicking in with unemployment coming down and it hasn't been. So she's got a hard decision to make on the economy. A harder decision - or a harder job is getting her 16 colleagues to agree with her. And as we lay out in this story, there's just a lot of people with different opinions.

SMITH: All right, Jon, thank you.

MCDOWELL: I'll tell people to read it because it's great.

SMITH: And Stephen Wood, thank you. And Jo Ling Kent, thank you.

WOOD: Thank you.

KENT: Thank you.

SMITH: We've got Walmart's new delivery service coming up next, about to lift off, putting the retail giant in the same new space has Amazon. And, by the way, a new poll out putting Dr. Carson at the top of the GOP candidates nationally. We're going to talk about that as well.

First, here are a few of the top headlines that we're watching in "The Wall Street Journal" this morning, including BP profit falling on weaker oil prices. Health insurance premiums set to climb in 2016. And that NASA spacecraft set for historic fly-by of one of Saturn's moons. We're coming right back. Stay with us.

SMITH: All right, we've got some new poll numbers just out giving Ben Carson a national lead. Cheryl Casone has this story and more.

Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: That's right, Sandra, good morning.

Ben Carson edging Donald Trump in a national poll for the first time. The latest CBS/"New York Times" poll gives Carson a four point lead over Trump, holding 26 percent of the vote. But, by the way, Iowa, we've been seeing Mr. Carson leading in Iowa. So big news, big news on this national scale today.

We've also got this for you. Another headache for the fantasy sports world. Legislation to regulate daily fantasy sports is expected to be introduced in Illinois today. This bill aims to protect consumers from draining - quote, "draining their bank accounts," as well as make sure they have a legitimate shot at winning on these sites.

And finally the battle of the drones heating up, this time with Walmart. The retailer applying for permission to test drones for home delivery, curbside pickup, checking warehouse inventories and this could be a sign that the retailer plans to go head to head with Amazon. Amazon's been very vocal, Sandra, obviously, about trying to get drones into the skies for delivery service and things.

Here's my question, do you want groceries delivered at your home via drone? Are you OK with that, comfortable with that?

SMITH: No.

CASONE: No? Interesting. Wow.

Well, Dagen, I know you -

MCDOWELL: Well, I - I think that there are some credible applications for drones, law enforcement -

SMITH: Yes.

MCDOWELL: You surveying land, even, you know, firefighting. But I just - I can't picture mass execution of drone delivery.

HILSENRATH: Well, so you talk about law enforcement. I think drones have a bad name because we've been using them for the last decade to shoot people from the sky. And - but you have to look at how this technology could get applied commercially. And if Amazon and Walmart think they can do it for logistics purposes, then more power to them. Let them try it.

CASONE: Let me ask you something, though. What happens when a drone that's delivering a package at 2 Cedar Street in Iowa hits a small child on a bike and there's a massive lawsuit. It - you know what I mean, like if you're Amazon or you're Walmart, they've got - their lawyers have to be thinking about this kind -

SMITH: Wait, wait, wait, wait but a FedEx truck could do the same thing.

CASONE: It could.

SMITH: Or a Walmart truck could do the same thing. So I don't know if that's -

HILSENRATH: Exactly.

CASONE: But drones make me - like I said earlier, drones make me so much more nervous.

SMITH: But, wait, did you just say that they're considering the drones for curbside pickup?

CASONE: Yes.

SMITH: Because I'm thinking that sounds even funnier.

CASONE: And (ph) delivery.

SMITH: Like you drive up to the store and a drone flies out.

MCDOWELL: Because I'm too lazy to get out of my car and actually go - go into the store.

SMITH: Fly out (ph).

HILSENRATH: But we - but we are. That's right. We have - that's why drive- through exists.

MCDOWELL: I'm not. I'm not.

HILSENRATH: But we - most Americans are. There would not be a thriving drive-through, you know, fast-food industry if we weren't all -

MCDOWELL: Oh, I love getting out of my car and going in the McD's and socializing.

HILSENRATH: Well, now you can just -

SMITH: What are you -

HILSENRATH: Now you can just pull into the McD's parking lot and your Big Mac will come to you.

SMITH: Cheryl, good stuff. Thank you.

CASONE: Yes.

SMITH: All right, after years of decline, U.S. imports of foreign oil are on the rise in the U.S. What does this mean for dropping gasoline prices here at home? We'll head to the CME for an answer, next.

SMITH: A top headline in "The Wall Street Journal" this morning. After years of decline, U.S. imports are on the rise. This as low oil prices force domestic producers to scale back supply.

Phil Flynn is at the CME Group in Chicago.

Will this push our crude oil prices higher, Phil?

PHIL FLYNN, CME GROUP: Well, right now they're pushing them lower. You know, it's put a lot of pressure on the market. You know, we're seeing these imports rise at a time when usually we see imports start to fall a little bit towards the end of the year. This is adding to the oil glut in the Gulf of Mexico where all that oil is. And it's also a sign that the U.S. oil producers are really losing the production war with the OPEC producers. Their production continues to stay strong, ours continue to fall. So this isn't really good news for the U.S. energy producer.

SMITH: All right. So, hey, by the way, we're looking at $43 for a barrel of crude.

FLYNN: Yes.

SMITH: What's the - what's consensus right now? What's - I mean the trend, obviously, as we look at a one week chart, has been down, Phil. But what are we looking at as far as price movement.

FLYNN: Yes.

SMITH: I know you watch the trend, the overall trend.

FLYNN: Right. Well, the mood is definitely negative, you know, and it's across the entire commodity complex. There's a lot of concern in the heart (ph) (INAUDIBLE) season. We're going to see that glut continue to build. You know, last week, you know, refinery runs were continuing to be below 90 percent as refiners are in maintenance (ph). So the demand for oil just isn't very strong. Now the good news is for gasoline prices, they have fallen 17 days in a row according to AAA.

SMITH: Wow.

FLYNN: The national average at $2.20. So if you want the bright side of the story, if you're not an oil producer, if you're a driver, you've got to love these prices.

SMITH: Well, Dagan, that would normally be the bright side of the story because that would mean that we could see a jump in consumer spending. That's extra cash in the pocket of the American consumer. But that hasn't happened yet, right?

MCDOWELL: It has happened somewhat. You wouldn't have record - a record holiday season at Amazon if it wasn't at least I think on the margins helping. And throughout the entire summer, you saw increases in small but nevertheless increases in consumer spending.

SMITH: To the economy.

MCDOWELL: I mean I don't -

HILSENRATH: And a boom - and a boom in car sales.

MCDOWELL: Yes, I - helped by extremely low interest rates for sure.

HILSENRATH: Right.

MCDOWELL: But there's a major auto boom going on and that - a lot of that has to do with the - the low energy prices.

HILSENRATH: But these - you know, these falling gasoline prices are happening at a great time because it's - it's happening going into the holiday shopping season.

SMITH: Yes.

HILSENRATH: So maybe we're going to see it this year.

SMITH: FedEx just reported yesterday, they expect record shipments. So at the same time they're expecting record shipments, up 12 percent they're saying year over year for this holiday season, they're also paying a heck of a lot more for the gasoline to get those boxes to the door.

MCDOWELL: Is Phil still standing there? I have a question for him.

SMITH: He is. Phil.

MCDOWELL: Hey, Phil.

FLYNN: Yes. Yes.

MCDOWELL: In terms of the production - any production pullback here in the United States with the frackers, is that destroyed forever or can they ramp production up assuming that these companies are healthy financially?

FLYNN: I think that - I think your final statement is the most important thing, how financially viable are these companies? In a perfect world, yes, they could turn the - turn it on very quickly. The problem is, where are they going to get the capital? A lot of these small - smaller fracking firms just don't have the capital to produce, so they're under a lot of pressure.

You know, the first time prices went up, we saw rig counts come back up. That's not going to happen again because the capital isn't going to be there.

HILSENRATH: But, Phil, I thought the private equity guys are standing on the sidelines ready to jump in because prices are so low and feed capital into the industry if it looks like there's a demand pickup.

FLYNN: Well, I think there was definitely money on the sidelines it's going to (INAUDIBLE) on the street. That doesn't mean it's going to, you know, save the entire industry. But there was another story that was really interest as well, is that China, one of the big real estate people in China, is buying up all the Texas oil fields.

SMITH: All right, Phil Flynn, always love having you. Thank you.

FLYNN: Thank you.

SMITH: Coming up, two D.C. outsider saying exactly what's on their minds despite the repercussions. Is the same brash style that's suddenly hurting Trump helping Carson? Have you seen the new national poll? That's next.

SMITH: Good morning. I'm Sandra Smith. Maria Bartiromo is off this morning. It is Tuesday, October 27th. And with me this hour, Fox Business' Dagen McDowell and "The Wall Street Journal's" Jon Hilsenrath.

Here are your top stories at 6:30 a.m., sorry, 7:30 a.m. Wow, time is flying when you're having fun

Donald Trump falling to second place now in a new national poll. It's the first time that we've seen him in this position. The latest CBS News/"New York Times" poll showing Ben Carson has the lead with 26 percent support. He has a four-point lead now over Trump, who has 22 percent. The rest of the field lagging far behind in the single digits. This after Trump's latest controversial comments on women, makeup and burqas.

TRUMP: In fact, it's easier. You don't have to put up makeup. Look how beautiful everyone looks. Wouldn't it be easier - wha - right, Wouldn't that be easy? I'll tell you, if I was a woman, I don't want to - wha, I'm ready, darling, let's go. It's true.

Congressional leaders and the White House reaching an agreement on a two year budget deal that also extends the debt limit. And a quick look at those markets this morning; not a lot of movement, as my father always used to say, sharply unchanged. Wal-Mart taking a page out of amazon's playbook. The retail giant wants to use drones to make deliveries to your front door. The company filing for regulatory approval. Wal-Mart also looking to use devices to check warehouse inventories and curbside pickup.
